member.name: M:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.RenderScene
member.summary: Only renders the 3D scene and the 2DUIs. Unlike the Draw function, this function doesn't perform physics update or scene graph updates. It simply renders the 3D scene. This method is useful when you need to render the scene more than once (e.g., when rendering multiple viewport or stereoscopic view).

member.name: M:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.RenderScene(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Only renders the 3D scene (and the 2DUIs if 'renderUI' is true). Unlike the Draw function, this function doesn't perform physics update or scene graph updates. It simply renders the 3D scene. This method is useful when you need to render the scene more than once (e.g., when rendering multiple viewport or stereoscopic view). Whether to renderUI

member.name: M:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.RenderScene(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Only renders the 3D scene (and the 2DUIs if 'renderUI' is true). Unlike the Draw function, this function doesn't perform physics update or scene graph updates if 'reTraverseScenegraph is false). It simply renders the 3D scene. This method is useful when you need to render the scene more than once (e.g., when rendering multiple viewport or stereoscopic view). Whether to renderUI Whether to re-traverse the scenegraph before rendering in the case the scene graph has changes

member.name: M:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.Update(System.TimeSpan,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Updates the scene graph.
member.remarks: For releases prior to version 4.0, you didn't need to call this Update method, but from version 4.0, you have to call this method in your Game.Update(...) method. This change enables the integration of Goblin XNA with WPF and Silverlight.
member.param: The elapsed game time (e.g., gameTime.ElasedGameTime)
Whether the game is running slow (e.g., gameTime.IsRunningSlowly)
Whether the game window is focused (e.g., this.IsActive)

member.name: M:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.Draw(System.TimeSpan,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Renders the scene graph.
member.remarks: For releases prior to version 4.0, you didn't need to call this Draw method, but from version 4.0, you have to call this method in your Game.Draw(...) method. This change enables the integration of Goblin XNA with WPF and Silverlight.
member.param: The elapsed game time (e.g., gameTime.ElasedGameTime)
Whether the game is running slow (e.g., gameTime.IsRunningSlowly)

member.name: M:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.Dispose
member.summary: Disposes the scene graph.
member.remarks: For releases prior to version 4.0, you didn't need to call this Dispose method, but from version 4.0, you have to call this method in your Game.Dispose(...) method. This change enables the integration of Goblin XNA with WPF and Silverlight.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.RootNode
member.summary: Gets or sets the root node of this scene graph
member.exception: If assigned to null

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.CameraNode
member.summary: Gets or sets the camera node of this scene graph. (There can be multiple camera nodes in one scene graph, but only one camera node should be active at a time.)

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.Environment
member.summary: Gets or sets the environment effect simulated in this scene including fog, rain, and sunflare.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.BackgroundTexture
member.summary: Gets or sets the background texture. If ShowCameraImage is set, this texture will be ignored. Also, if this texture is set, the BackgroundColor will be ignored.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.BackgroundBound
member.summary: Gets or sets the background bound for video texture and 'BackgroundTexture' set by the user. If not set, it will use the full window dimension (which will cause stretching if the size of the texture and the window size is different)

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.BackgroundColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the background color. If either ShowCameraImage or BackgroundTexture is set, this will be ignored. Default color is Color.CornflowerBlue.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.BackgroundTextureEffects
member.summary: Gets or sets the sprite effects to apply to the BackgroundTexture.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.VideoBackgroundColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the background color mixed with the video image. This is applicable only when ShowCameraImage is set to true. Default color is Color.White.
member.remarks: You can use this property to, for example, modify the transparency of the video image or mix a color to it.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.SceneRenderTarget
member.summary: Gets or sets the render target in which the scene will be rendered. The default value is null, which is the back buffer.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.TransparencyDrawOrderComparer
member.summary: Gets or sets the comparer for sorting the drawing order of transparent geometries. If not set, then a default transparency comparer which compares the distance between center of the bounding volume of the geometry and the currently active camera location.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.MarkerTracker
member.summary: Gets or sets the marker tracking system.
member.remarks: If you already assigned the CameraNode, then its projection matrix will be modified to match the projection matrix of the marker tracker.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.VideoCaptures
member.summary: Gets a list of video capture instances.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.PhysicsEngine
member.summary: Gets or sets the specific physics engine implementation used for this scene graph.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.RenderAxisAlignedBoundingBox
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to render the axis-aligned bounding box generated by the physics engine of your choice. Note that the IPhysics function GetAxisAlignedBoundingBox must be implemented correctly in order to render correctly.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.RenderCollisionMesh
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to render the actual mesh used for collision detection by the physics engine of your choice. Note that the IPhysics function GetCollisionMesh must be implemented correctly in order to render correctly.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.NetworkHandler
member.summary: Gets or sets the network handler implementation used for this scene graph.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.UIRenderer
member.summary: Gets the UI renderer used in this scene. Use this property to add any UI components to be rendered in the scene.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.EnableShadowMapping
member.summary: Gets or sets whether shadow mapping should be enabled. The default value is false.
member.remarks: Make sure to set the ShadowMap property if you set this property to true.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.ShadowMap
member.summary: Gets or sets the shader for shadow mapping.
member.remarks: By setting this property, EnableShadowMapping property will be automatically set to true if the ShadowMap is not null.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.EnableLighting
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to enable the lighting in the scene. The default value is true.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.EnableFrustumCulling
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to enable culling on each geometry node based on whether the node is inside of the current camera frustum. The default value is true.
member.remarks: If your application is CPU bound, then setting this to false can improve the performance. However, if your application is GPU bound, then leaving this value to true would have better performance.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.AabbColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the color used to draw the axis-aligned bounding box of each model for debugging. Default color is Color.YellowGreen.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.CollisionMeshColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the color used to draw the actual mesh used for collision detection of each model for debugging. Default color is Color.Purple.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.FPS
member.summary: Gets the current Frames Per Second count

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.TriangleCount
member.summary: Gets the current triangle count

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.ShowCameraImage
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to show camera captured physical image in the background. By default, this is false.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.OverlayVideoID
member.summary: Gets or sets the video capture device ID used to provide the overlaid physical image. This ID should correspond to the videoDeviceID given to the initialized video device using InitVideoCapture method.
member.remarks: Getting or setting this property is exactly same as getting or setting the LeftEyeVideoID property.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.TrackerVideoID
member.summary: Gets or sets the video capture device ID used to perform marker tracking (if available). This ID should correspond to the index in the VideoCaptures property, which is basically the order you have added the IVideoCapture through AddVideoCaptureDevice method.
member.remarks: Note that the notion of this ID has changed from Goblin XNA 3.x series.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.LeftEyeVideoID
member.summary: Gets or sets the video ID for left eye to use for stereo augmented reality. If you use single camera for stereo, then you should set both LeftEyeVideoID and RightEyeVideoID to the same ID. This ID should correspond to the index in the VideoCaptures property, which is basically the order you have added the IVideoCapture through AddVideoCaptureDevice method.
member.remarks: Note that the notion of this ID has changed from Goblin XNA 3.x series.
member.exception: If video ID is not valid or your camera node does not contain stereo information.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.RightEyeVideoID
member.summary: Gets or sets the video ID for right eye to use for stereo augmented reality. If you use single camera for stereo, then you should set both LeftEyeVideoID and RightEyeVideoID to the same ID. This ID should correspond to the index in the VideoCaptures property, which is basically the order you have added the IVideoCapture through AddVideoCaptureDevice method.
member.remarks: Note that the notion of this ID has changed from Goblin XNA 3.x series.
member.exception: If video ID is not valid or your camera node does not contain stereo information.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.FreezeVideo
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to freeze currently active video streaming.
member.remarks: This will also affect the vision tracking if tracking is used.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.RenderBeforeBackgroundCallback
member.summary: Gets or sets the callback function that is invoked before rendering the background texture including the video texture.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.RenderAfterBackgroundCallback
member.summary: Gets or sets the callback function that is invoked after rendering the background texture including the video texture, but before rendering the 3D scene objects.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.RenderBeforeUICallback
member.summary: Gets or sets the callback function that is invoked after all 3D geometries are rendered, but right before the 2D UIs are rendered.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.RenderAfterUICallback
member.summary: Gets or sets the callback function that is invoked after the 2D UIs are rendered.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.NeedsImagePtr
member.summary: Gets or sets whether you need the image pointer to be passed back by your IVideoCapture.GetTextureImage(...) even if it is not needed by the Scene class. Default value is false. Use this with caution.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.NeedsImageData
member.summary: Gets or sets whether you need the image data (int array) to be passed back by your IVideoCapture.GetTextureImage(...) even if it is not needed by the Scene class. Default value is false. Use this with caution.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.GlobalUIShift
member.summary: Gets or sets the shift amount applied to all 2D HUD drawings including the text in the X screen coordinate.
member.remarks: This shift is applied only when right eye view is rendered in stereo mode.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.RenderLeftView
member.summary: Gets whether the scene graph is currently rendering the left eye view when in stereo mode.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.AlwaysSortTransparency
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to always sort transparent objects in the scene. It's best to set this to true if you have objects with Diffuse.W less than 1 in AR mode.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.Processing
member.summary: Indicates whether the scene graph is currently being traversed.

member.name: P:GoblinXNA.SceneGraph.Scene.IsStarted
member.summary: Indicates whether the scene processing has already started.
member.remarks: This is used to check whether adding nodes outside of tree traversal is exception free.

member.name: M:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.ModifyPhysicsObject(GoblinXNA.Physics.IPhysicsObject,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Matrix)
member.summary: Not implemented yet.

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.SolverType.SOLVER_TYPE_2ITERS_SOFT
member.summary: 'Softest' solver type.

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.SolverType.SOLVER_TYPE_8ITERS_HARD
member.summary: 'Hardest' solver type.

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.SimulationType.SIMULATION_TYPE_DISCRETE
member.summary: No continuous simulation is performed

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.SimulationType.SIMULATION_TYPE_CONTINUOUS
member.summary: Use this simulation if you want any continuous simulation. Depending on the hkpEntity->getQualityType(), collisions are not only performed at 'normal' physical timesteps (called PSI), but at any time when two objects collide (TOI)

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.SimulationType.SIMULATION_TYPE_MULTITHREADED
member.summary: Multithreaded continuous simulation. You must have read the multi threading user guide. To use this you should call hkpWorld::stepMultithreaded(), see the hkDefaultPhysicsDemo::stepDemo for an example. Notes: - The internal overhead for multi threaded is small and you can expect good speedups, except: - solving multiple TOI events can not be done on different threads, so TOI are solved on a single thread. However the collision detection for each TOI event can be solver multithreaded (see m_processToisMultithreaded)

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.MotionType.MOTION_DYNAMIC
member.summary: A fully-simulated, movable rigid body. At construction time the engine checks the input inertia and selects MOTION_SPHERE_INERTIA or MOTION_BOX_INERTIA as appropriate.

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.MotionType.MOTION_SPHERE_INERTIA
member.summary: Simulation is performed using a sphere inertia tensor. (A multiple of the Identity matrix). The highest value of the diagonal of the rigid body's inertia tensor is used as the spherical inertia.

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.MotionType.MOTION_BOX_INERTIA
member.summary: Simulation is performed using a box inertia tensor. The non-diagonal elements of the inertia tensor are set to zero. This is slower than the MOTION_SPHERE_INERTIA motions, however it can produce more accurate results, especially for long thin objects.

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.MotionType.MOTION_KEYFRAMED
member.summary: Simulation is not performed as a normal rigid body. During a simulation step, the velocity of the rigid body is used to calculate the new position of the rigid body, however the velocity is NOT updated. The user can keyframe a rigid body by setting the velocity of the rigid body to produce the desired keyframe positions. The hkpKeyFrameUtility class can be used to simply apply keyframes in this way. The velocity of a keyframed rigid body is NOT changed by the application of impulses or forces. The keyframed rigid body has an infinite mass when viewed by the rest of the system.

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.MotionType.MOTION_FIXED
member.summary: This motion type is used for the static elements of a game scene, e.g. the landscape. Fixed rigid bodies are treated in a special way by the system. They have the same effect as a rigid body with a motion of type MOTION_KEYFRAMED and velocity 0, however they are much faster to use, incurring no simulation overhead, except in collision with moving bodies.

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.MotionType.MOTION_THIN_BOX_INERTIA
member.summary: A box inertia motion which is optimized for thin boxes and has less stability problems

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.MotionType.MOTION_CHARACTER
member.summary: A specialized motion used for character controllers

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.CollidableQualityType.COLLIDABLE_QUALITY_INVALID
member.summary: Invalid or unassinged type. If you add a hkpRigidBody to the hkpWorld, this type automatically gets converted to either COLLIDABLE_QUALITY_FIXED, COLLIDABLE_QUALITY_KEYFRAMED or COLLIDABLE_QUALITY_DEBRIS

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.CollidableQualityType.COLLIDABLE_QUALITY_FIXED
member.summary: Use this for fixed bodies.

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.CollidableQualityType.COLLIDABLE_QUALITY_KEYFRAMED
member.summary: Use this for moving objects with infinite mass.

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.CollidableQualityType.COLLIDABLE_QUALITY_DEBRIS
member.summary: Use this for all your debris objects

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.CollidableQualityType.COLLIDABLE_QUALITY_DEBRIS_SIMPLE_TOI
member.summary: Use this for debris objects that should have simplified Toi collisions with fixed/landscape objects.

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.CollidableQualityType.COLLIDABLE_QUALITY_MOVING
member.summary: Use this for moving bodies, which should not leave the world, but you rather prefer those objects to tunnel through the world than dropping frames because the engine

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.CollidableQualityType.COLLIDABLE_QUALITY_CRITICAL
member.summary: Use this for all objects, which you cannot afford to tunnel through the world at all

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.CollidableQualityType.COLLIDABLE_QUALITY_BULLET
member.summary: Use this for very fast objects

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.CollidableQualityType.COLLIDABLE_QUALITY_USER
member.summary: For user. If you want to use this, you have to modify hkpCollisionDispatcher::initCollisionQualityInfo()

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.CollidableQualityType.COLLIDABLE_QUALITY_CHARACTER
member.summary: Use this for rigid body character controllers

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.CollidableQualityType.COLLIDABLE_QUALITY_KEYFRAMED_REPORTING
member.summary:
Use this for moving objects with infinite mass which should report contact points and Toi-collisions against all other bodies, including other fixed and keyframed bodies.
Note that only non-Toi contact points are reported in collisions against debris-quality objects.

member.name: F:GoblinXNA.Physics.Havok.HavokPhysics.CollidableQualityType.COLLIDABLE_QUALITY_MAX
member.summary: End of this list

member.name: T:GoblinXNA.Graphics.ParticleEffects.ParticleEmitter
member.summary:
Helper for objects that want to leave particles behind them as they move around the world. This emitter implementation solves two related problems:
If an object wants to create particles very slowly, less than once per frame, it can be a pain to keep track of updates that ought to create a new particle versus those that should not.
If an object is moving quickly and is creating many particles per frame, it will look ugly if these particles are all bunched up together. Much better if they can be spread out along a line between where the object is now and where it was on the previous frame. This is particularly important for leaving trails behind fast moving objects such as rockets.
This emitter class keeps track of a moving object, remembering its previous position so it can calculate the velocity of the object. It works out the perfect locations for creating particles at any frequency you specify, regardless of whether this is faster or slower than the game update rate.

member.name: M:GoblinXNA.Graphics.ParticleEffects.ParticleEmitter.#ctor(GoblinXNA.Graphics.ParticleEffects.ParticleEffect,System.Single,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector3)

member.name: M:GoblinXNA.Graphics.ParticleEffects.ParticleEmitter.Update(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GameTime,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector3)
member.summary: Updates the emitter, creating the appropriate number of particles in the appropriate positions.

member.name: T:GoblinXNA.Device.Util.DESPredictor
member.summary: A predictor that implements La Viola's Double Exponentional Smoothing Prediction algorithm.

member.name: M:GoblinXNA.Device.Util.DESPredictor.#ctor(System.Single,System.Single,System.Int32,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Creates a double-exponential-smoothing predictor with the specified alpha values, delta time increment, and thresholds.
member.param: An alpha value used for translational smoothing.
An alpha value used for rotational smoothing.
The time delta between each prediction time

A translational threshold. If set to larger than 0, then if the distance between the previous transformation and the current transformation is larger than this threshold, then the current transformation will be dropped from the smoothing calculation.

A rotational threshold. If set to largen than 0, then if the angle (in radians) between the previous transformation and the current transformation is larger than this threshold, then the current transformation will be dropped from the smoothing calculation.

member.summary: Creates a double-exponential-smoothing predictor with the specified alpha value, and delta time increment with no thresholds.

The time delta between each prediction time.
